newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Nobel Prize winners gather in Sweden for awards.
newsitem.headline: Nobel Prize winners gather in Sweden for awards.

text.p: The 1996 Nobel prize winners have gathered in Stockholm to receive their prestigious awards and attend a banquet on Tuesday, the 100th anniversary of founder Alfred Nobel's death.

The winners of five of the six awards will receive Nobel gold medals and cheques of $1.2 million a prize from Sweden's King Carl XVI Gustaf at a formal ceremony before joining 1,300 guests for a black tie dinner that will be televised live.

The winners of the 1996 Nobel peace prize, East Timor's Bishop Carlos Belo and resistance leader Jose Ramos-Horta, will receive their awards in Oslo in neighbouring Norway as stipulated in the will of Nobel, a Swedish scientist.
The joint winner of the 1996 economics award, Canadian William Vickrey, 82, died from a heart attack three days after winning the prize.
His friend and colleague, Professor C. Lowell Harris, will receive the prize on his behalf.
The Columbia University professor won the prize jointly with Briton James Mirrlees for their separate contributions to the economic theory of incentives under asymmetric information.
Polish poet and critic Wislawa Szymborska, who has been described as the "Mozart of Poetry", was awarded the literature prize.

The Swedish Academy said the shy, chain-smoking poet deserved the prize "for her poetry that with ironic precision allows the historical and biological context to come to light in fragments of human reality".

The scientific prizes, first awarded in 1901 at the bequest of Nobel, have once again been dominated by Americans, confirming a widely held view that U.S. colleges are producing the world's best scientific research.
Some of the winners at a news conference in Stockholm voiced concern about continuing cutbacks in government funding for basic research around the world.
"Directed research can never replace basic research," said chemistry prize winner American Robert Curl.
"In basic research, you never know what will happen, you can never promise any results. Directed research had never given us laser and we would never have discovered our own DNA."

Curl shared the chemistry prize with fellow countryman Richard Smalley and Briton Sir Harold Kroto for a 1985 discovery of a form of the carbon element in the faceted shape of a soccer ball, which gave rise to a new form of chemistry.

The physics prize was awarded to the U.S. trio of David Lee, Douglas Osheroff and Robert Richardson for their quantum physics discovery on the superfluidity of the helium-3 isotope, a breakthrough in low temperature physics.

The medicine prize went to Australian Peter Doherty and Switzerland's Rolf Zinkernagel for discovering how the immune system recognises and can then kill infected cells, unlocking the mystery of how a vaccine needs to be composed.
